conclusion: ETC is the abbreviation for Electronic Toll Collection system. Recently, the traffic speed at an ETC lane in Chongqing has increased from 20 km/h to 40 km/h.
A car travels at a constant velocity of v0 = 30 m/s towards the toll station along a straight line.

The car needs to decelerate uniformly to v1 = 5 m/s exactly d = 10 m before the center line of the toll station, then pass through the center line at constant velocity, and finally accelerate uniformly back to v0 for normal driving.
The magnitude of the car's acceleration and deceleration is 1 m/s² in both processes, and the length of the car body is neglected.

The image shows a car traveling along a lane with a toll booth at the end. The car decelerates uniformly from v0 = 30 m/s to v1 = 5 m/s over a distance d = 10 m. After passing the center line, it accelerates uniformly back to v0.
Calculate the time t1 it takes to decelerate from v0 = 30 m/s to v1 = 5 m/s using the deceleration a = 1 m/s²: t1 = (v0 - v1) / a = (30 - 5) / 1 = 25 s.
Find the distance traveled during deceleration: s1 = v0 * t1 - (1/2) * a * t1² = 30 * 25 - (1/2) * 1 * 25² = 250 m.
Calculate the distance d traveled at constant velocity: d = 10 m.
Find the time t2 to accelerate from v1 = 5 m/s back to v0 = 30 m/s using the same deceleration: t2 = (v0 - v1) / a = (30 - 5) / 1 = 25 s.
Calculate the distance traveled during acceleration: s2 = v1 * t2 + (1/2) * a * t2² = 5 * 25 + (1/2) * 1 * 25² = 250 m.
The total displacement is the sum of the distances traveled during deceleration, constant velocity, and acceleration: S = s1 + d + s2 = 250 + 10 + 250 = 510 m.
The magnitude of the displacement of the car during the process is 510 m.
